metadata.title: UK Democracy - Expert Challenge
metadata.description: Challenging questions about UK democracy designed to test detailed knowledge
metadata.subject: Advanced UK Democracy and Government

questions.question: Which of the following accurately describes the Salisbury Convention?
choices: The House of Lords should not reject legislation promised in the government's election manifesto
The Prime Minister must consult Cabinet before dissolving Parliament
All bills must be read three times in each House
The monarch cannot refuse royal assent to any bill
questions.explanation: The Salisbury Convention is an important constitutional convention that the House of Lords should not oppose bills implementing the governing party's election manifesto commitments.

questions.question: The 'West Lothian Question' refers to:
choices: Whether Scottish MPs can vote on England-only matters at Westminster
The boundary disputes between England and Scotland
The right of Scottish Parliament to override UK law
The method of electing Scottish MPs to Westminster
questions.explanation: The West Lothian Question asks whether it's fair for Scottish MPs to vote on England-only matters when English MPs cannot vote on devolved Scottish matters.

questions.question: Under the current rules, how many hereditary peers can sit in the House of Lords?
choices: None - all hereditary peers were removed
92 hereditary peers
Any number if they are elected
Only those who also hold life peerages
questions.explanation: Since the House of Lords Act 1999, only 92 hereditary peers can remain: 90 elected by their fellow hereditary peers plus the Earl Marshal and Lord Great Chamberlain.

questions.question: The 'payroll vote' in the House of Commons refers to:
choices: MPs voting on their own salaries
Government ministers and parliamentary private secretaries who usually support the government
MPs who are paid by lobby groups
The final vote on the annual budget
questions.explanation: The payroll vote consists of government ministers and parliamentary private secretaries (around 140 MPs) who are expected to support government policy or resign.

questions.question: Which voting system is used for electing the London Assembly?
choices: First Past the Post throughout
Single Transferable Vote
Additional Member System
Alternative Vote Plus
questions.explanation: The London Assembly uses the Additional Member System with 14 constituency members (FPTP) and 11 London-wide members (proportional representation).

questions.question: The Barnett Formula determines:
choices: How constituency boundaries are drawn
How public spending is allocated between UK nations
The number of peers in the House of Lords
When general elections must be held
questions.explanation: The Barnett Formula is used to calculate the annual adjustments to public spending allocated to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland relative to England.

questions.question: Under the Fixed-term Parliaments Act 2011 (now repealed), early elections could be triggered by:
choices: A simple majority vote of MPs
Two-thirds of all MPs voting for dissolution
The Prime Minister requesting the monarch
A referendum on early dissolution
questions.explanation: The Act required either a two-thirds majority of all MPs or a successful motion of no confidence followed by 14 days without a new government being formed.

questions.question: The role of the Lord Privy Seal is:
choices: To control access to the Royal Seal
A senior Cabinet position often without specific departmental duties
To oversee the House of Lords
To advise the monarch on constitutional matters
questions.explanation: The Lord Privy Seal is typically a senior Cabinet minister without specific departmental responsibilities, often taking on coordinating roles across government.

questions.question: What is meant by 'collective ministerial responsibility'?
choices: All ministers share responsibility for government policy publicly
Ministers can only be dismissed together
Cabinet decisions must be unanimous
All ministers must come from the same political party
questions.explanation: Collective responsibility means all ministers must publicly support government policy, even if they disagreed in private, or else resign from government.

questions.question: The English Votes for English Laws (EVEL) procedure was designed to:
choices: Prevent Scottish MPs voting on England-only legislation
Create a separate English Parliament
Give English regions more autonomy
Reduce the number of English constituencies
questions.explanation: EVEL (2015-2021) gave English (or English and Welsh) MPs a decisive say over legislation affecting only England, addressing the West Lothian Question partially.

questions.question: A 'money bill' in the UK Parliament is:
choices: Any bill involving government spending
A bill certified by the Speaker as dealing only with taxation or public money
The annual Budget bill only
Any bill that affects the Bank of England
questions.explanation: A money bill must be certified by the Speaker as dealing only with specified financial matters. The House of Lords can only delay it for one month.

questions.question: The 'Sewell Convention' states that:
choices: The UK Parliament will not normally legislate on devolved matters without consent
Scottish law takes precedence over UK law in Scotland
The Scottish Parliament cannot be dissolved without consent
Scottish ministers must attend UK Cabinet meetings
questions.explanation: The Sewell Convention holds that the UK Parliament will not normally legislate on devolved matters without the consent of the relevant devolved legislature.

questions.question: Which principle prevents the courts from questioning proceedings in Parliament?
choices: Parliamentary sovereignty
Parliamentary privilege
Collective responsibility
The separation of powers
questions.explanation: Parliamentary privilege protects freedom of speech in Parliament and prevents courts from questioning what is said or done in parliamentary proceedings.

questions.question: The Constitutional Reform Act 2005 created:
choices: The Scottish Parliament
The Supreme Court and reformed the Lord Chancellor's role
The Barnett Formula
The Fixed-term Parliaments Act
questions.explanation: The Act created the UK Supreme Court, transferred judicial functions from the House of Lords, and reduced the Lord Chancellor's judicial powers to improve separation of powers.

questions.question: A 'statutory instrument' is:
choices: A type of Act of Parliament
Secondary legislation made under powers granted by primary legislation
A legal document signed by the monarch
A court order interpreting the law
questions.explanation: Statutory instruments are secondary legislation allowing ministers to make detailed regulations under powers granted by Acts of Parliament, avoiding the need for new primary legislation.
